deliberation: I considered whether the vision report itself is symbolic or figurative. In this verse the prophet simply reports what YHWH showed him (two baskets of figs before the temple) and gives precise historical context of Jeconiah’s exile. The symbolic meaning of the figs is not yet stated here; it is only interpreted later (vv.5, 8). The language in v.1 is narrative and descriptive, not employing metaphor, simile, or other figures on its own.

I checked for explicit comparison markers and exaggeration. The clause כִּתְאֵנֵי הַבַּכֻּרוֹת is a clear simile comparing the good figs to prized first-ripened figs. The statement that the bad figs are so bad they cannot be eaten can be literally true (inedible produce) and does not require hyperbole. The good/bad figs here are still literal within the vision; their representative function is only defined in vv.5, 8.

instances.explanation: The figs in one basket are explicitly compared, by means of כִּ, to first-ripened figs, evoking the special excellence and desirability of such early fruit.

deliberation: I considered whether Jeremiah’s repetition introduces figurative meaning. Here he simply restates what he sees—good figs very good, bad figs very bad—in response to a divine question. No new comparison marker appears, and the verse does not yet map the figs to people or conditions. The language is emphatic but not figurative.

I examined the prophetic formula וַיְהִי דְבַר־יְהוָה אֵלַי. This conventional expression treats the ‘word’ as an entity that ‘comes’ to the prophet, which is a conceptual metaphor and mild personification of the divine message as an approaching agent or object. No other figures occur.

deliberation: I looked for explicit comparison signals and for the point where the vision is interpreted. The particle כַּ plus כֵּן sets up a simile: the good figs correspond to the Judean exiles whom YHWH will regard for good. This is the interpretive move that connects the fig image to a human group. Other phrases in the verse are straightforward theological explanation of exile, not figures.

deliberation: I examined three clauses for figurative language: (1) ‘I will set my eye upon them for good’ anthropomorphically portrays God’s favorable attention as an ‘eye’ directed toward them. (2) ‘I will build them and not tear down’ treats the people as a structure God constructs, echoing Jeremiah 1:10; this is metaphorical. (3) ‘I will plant them and not uproot’ likens the restored community to a planted organism made secure in the land. These are three distinct but related metaphors.

deliberation: I focused on the use of ‘heart’ (לֵב). ‘I will give them a heart to know Me’ and ‘they will return to Me with all their heart’ employ ‘heart’ metonymically for the inner cognitive-volitional self. The covenant formula ‘they will be My people and I will be their God’ is a relational statement, but not necessarily figurative in itself. The primary figure is the heart as the center of understanding and commitment.

deliberation: I looked for the counterpart to the good-figs comparison. The construction וְכַ… כֵּן again signals a simile: the bad, inedible figs correspond to Zedekiah, his officials, and the remaining Judeans (including those in Egypt). The verse uses the previously described figs as an image for the worthlessness and doom of this group.

deliberation: I evaluated the series of nouns describing what God will ‘make’ them: horror, disgrace, proverb, byword, curse. They do not literally become these abstractions; rather, they become objects that evoke horror and are spoken of as proverbs and curses among the nations. This is one composite metaphor/metonymy cluster about their reputation and exemplary misfortune.

deliberation: I checked the triad ‘sword, famine, and pestilence’ and the verb ‘send.’ ‘Sword’ stands metonymically for warfare/violent death, and all three are treated as agents that can be ‘sent,’ which personifies them slightly. The phrase ‘until they are consumed from the land’ can be literally fulfilled in terms of population removal and need not be read as hyperbole. The main figurative element is the metonymic triad used for forms of judgment.
